factoid: The narrator awoke late.
The narrator read the Scriptures.
The narrator was apathetic after reading the Scriptures.
The narrator paced up and down the large hall.
The narrator wished to meditate.
The narrator's imagination pictured an occurrence that happened four years ago.
Dólokhov met the narrator in Moscow after their duel.
Dólokhov said he hoped the narrator was enjoying perfect peace of mind in spite of the narrator's wife's absence.
The narrator gave Dólokhov no answer at the time.
The narrator recalled every detail of that meeting.
The narrator gave Dólokhov the most malevolent and bitter replies in his mind.
The narrator recollected himself and drove away that thought only when he found himself glowing with anger.
The narrator did not sufficiently repent.
Borís Drubetskóy came after dinner.
Borís Drubetskóy began relating various adventures.
Borís Drubetskóy's coming vexed the narrator from the first.
The narrator said something disagreeable to Borís Drubetskóy.
Borís Drubetskóy replied.
The narrator flared up and said much that was unpleasant and even rude to Borís Drubetskóy.
Borís Drubetskóy became silent.
The narrator recollected himself only when it was too late.
The narrator cannot get on with Borís Drubetskóy at all.
The narrator's egotism is the cause of this.
The narrator set himself above Borís Drubetskóy.
The narrator became much worse than Borís Drubetskóy.
Borís Drubetskóy is lenient to the narrator's rudeness.
The narrator nourishes contempt for Borís Drubetskóy.
The narrator asks God to see his own vileness in Borís Drubetskóy's presence.
The narrator asks to behave so that Borís Drubetskóy may benefit.
After dinner the narrator fell asleep.
While drowsing off the narrator clearly heard a voice saying in his left ear, "Thy day!"
The narrator dreamed he was walking in the dark.
The narrator was suddenly surrounded by dogs.
The narrator went on undismayed.
A smallish dog seized the narrator's left thigh with its teeth and would not let go.
The narrator began to throttle the smallish dog with his hands.
The narrator tore the smallish dog off before another bigger dog began biting him.
The narrator lifted the bigger dog up.
The bigger dog grew larger and heavier the higher the narrator lifted it.
Brother A. came and took the narrator's arm.
Brother A. led the narrator to a building to enter which they had to pass along a narrow plank.
The narrator stepped on the narrow plank, but it bent and gave way.
The narrator began to clamber up a fence he could scarcely reach with his hands.
The narrator dragged himself up, so that his leg hung down on one side and his body on the other.
The narrator looked round and saw Brother A. standing on the fence and pointing him to a broad avenue and garden.
In the garden there was a large and beautiful building.
The narrator woke up.
The narrator calls God "great Architect of Nature".
The narrator asks God to help him tear from himself these dogs—his passions especially the last.
The narrator asks God to aid him to enter that temple of virtue to a vision of which he attained in his dream.
The event occurred on 7th December.
The narrator's wife was absent.
The narrator was glowing with anger.
